channel.title: MorningBrew as a feed
channel.description: This is a feed of recent MorningBrew articles published by Huginn

item.title: There‚Äôs a sriracha shortage and it‚Äôs expected to last through summer
item.description: . Become smarter in just 5 minutesGet the daily email that makes reading the news actually enjoyable. The light at the end of the bottle: Other sriracha brands have not announced pepper problems and may source their peppers elsewhere, so for now the shortage seems like a Huy Fong problem. ‚ÄîMK css-1dlcpt7[data-readonly]{box-shadow:none!
item.author: Max Knoblauch

item.title: Thailand becomes first Asian country to decriminalize medical, industrial marijuana
item.description: . Become smarter in just 5 minutesGet the daily email that makes reading the news actually enjoyable. ‚ÄîMM css-1dlcpt7[data-readonly]{box-shadow:none! The details: Individuals can grow and trade cannabis products without violating the law, medical facilities are allowed to prescribe the drug, and restaurants can offer you a morning latte with a schtickle of THC. And even though the move could help the country rejuvenate its Covid-ravaged tourism industry, Thailand made it very clear that it‚Äôs not trying to be the next Boulder.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Gas prices hit $5 per gallon nationally, GasBuddy says
item.description: . Become smarter in just 5 minutesGet the daily email that makes reading the news actually enjoyable. Law enforcement: A sheriff‚Äôs department in Michigan instructed its deputies to cut back on visits for non-urgent calls because it had blasted through its fuel budget with months before a new one kicks in. A ‚Äúperfect storm‚Äù of variables has aligned to drive gas prices higher this summer, GasBuddy‚Äôs Head of Petroleum Analysis Patrick De Haan wrote, leading to a severe supply‚Äìdemand imbalance that could drag on like the final two minutes of an NBA game.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: SEC Chair Gary Gensler proposes new stock trading rules
item.description: . Become smarter in just 5 minutesGet the daily email that makes reading the news actually enjoyable. The proposed solution: Make brokers like Robinhood route investors‚Äô trades to auctions, where Wall Street firms could compete to execute the trades‚Äîeffectively, if not explicitly, ending the ‚Äúpayment for order flow‚Äù relationship. SEC Chair Gary Gensler floated a number of ideas to revamp Wall Street‚Äôs plumbing network, but perhaps the most significant change would affect the ‚Äúpayment for order flow‚Äù model, which came under fire during the meme stock bonanza last year. ‚ÄîJW css-1dlcpt7[data-readonly]{box-shadow:none! css-y2oq5g[data-hover][data-disabled]{background:var(--colors-primary);opacity:0.5;}SubscribeOver a year since Reddit traders sent meme stocks like GameStop to the moon, the SEC (Wall Street‚Äôs top cop) is making its first moves to overhaul the way individual trades are conducted. It works like this:Wholesalers like Citadel pay brokerages like Robinhood a small fee to execute individuals‚Äô trades‚Äîand they make a small profit.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: LIV Golf league tees off in formidable challenge to PGA Tour
item.description: . Dustin Johnson, the former No. 1 player in the world, made $74 million in career earnings on the PGA Tour. Why LIV is able to shell out these huge sums is also what makes it so controversial: It‚Äôs backed by the Saudi Arabian government, which has been accused of numerous human rights abuses, including the murder of journalist Jamal Khashoggi in 2018. Become smarter in just 5 minutesGet the daily email that makes reading the news actually enjoyable. But he added, ‚ÄúIf Saudi Arabia wanted to use the game of golf as a way for them to get to where they want to be and they have the resources to accelerate that experience, I think we are proud to help them on that journey‚Ä¶‚ÄùLooking ahead‚Ä¶LIV‚Äôs potential to disrupt professional golf will hinge on its ability to woo even more top players into its ranks. LIV Golf will reportedly pay him $125 million before he even swings a club.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Taco Bell opens futuristic new location in Minnesota
item.description: . Become smarter in just 5 minutesGet the daily email that makes reading the news actually enjoyable. )If you want a more classic fast-food experience, you can drive through the one traditional lane or head inside the restaurant to order on a touchscreen or pick up a mobile order‚Äîbut there‚Äôs no place to sit. Imagine this: After ordering a Mexican Pizza and a Baja Blast on your phone, you drive up to a screen at the front of one of four drive-thru lanes, scan a QR code, and have your order descend from the restaurant overhead through a tubular contraption. Franchisee Border Foods observed that drive-thru orders at its 230 locations jumped from up to 70% of total sales before Covid-19 to over 90% now. ‚ÄîJW Border Foods CEO Lee Engler told Axios, ‚ÄúWe saw a lot of behavior change, and we don‚Äôt see (the old way) coming back.‚Äù
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: California court rules bees are legally fish again
item.description: . Become smarter in just 5 minutesGet the daily email that makes reading the news actually enjoyable. The new classification protects bees‚Äîand other insects‚Äîunder the California Endangered Species Act (CESA), and is the culmination of a four-year legal tussle between environmentalists and agriculture groups that has major consequences for farmers in the state. In 2020, a Sacramento County Superior Court sided with the ag groups and reversed the 2018 ruling. ‚ÄîMM css-1dlcpt7[data-readonly]{box-shadow:none! css-y2oq5g[data-hover][data-disabled]{background:var(--colors-primary);opacity:0.5;}SubscribeIn a ruling ripe for a Jay Leno monologue, a California court said last week that bees are legally fish. The court even ruled that anything without a backbone qualifies as fish: jellyfish, insects, and you when your mom guilts you into going on a family vacation. Section 45 of CESA defines fish as ‚Äú... So in 2018, three environmental groups that were worried about the declining pollinator population in California found a workaround to expand the legal definition of fish to cover four species of endangered bees.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Target takes action to reduce massive inventory glut
item.description: . Become smarter in just 5 minutesGet the daily email that makes reading the news actually enjoyable. And the data supports the theory that the American shopper is holding up just fine‚Ä¶for now: US consumer spending grew at the fastest clip in three months in April, when adjusting for inflation. What happened: In trying to solve one problem (Covid-related shortages), retailers created another (a surplus of the kinds of goods people don‚Äôt want to buy right now).
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Taco Bell opens futuristic new location in Minnesota
item.description: . item.title: Axon pumps the brakes on taser drone it said could take down mass shooters
item.description: . Become smarter in just 5 minutesGet the daily email that makes reading the news actually enjoyable. The hard pivot comes after Axon founder and CEO Rick Smith announced last week that the security company would start development of drones that could be operated by first responders and potentially used in schools to avoid another shooting like the recent one in Uvalde, Texas. ‚ÄîMM What changed? Axon‚Äôs ethics board, a group of experts in tech, privacy, and policing, sparred publicly with Smith over the idea, arguing that the drones could be used to over-police communities of color. In 2016, Smith even wrote a companion graphic novel exploring how the drone could stop a shooter. Nine members resigned yesterday over the drone plan.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Elon Musk tries to squirm out of Twitter deal
item.description: . Become smarter in just 5 minutesGet the daily email that makes reading the news actually enjoyable. Big picture: One reason for Musk‚Äôs fixation with bots might be that he encounters them far more than the average Twitter user‚Äîor even the average celebrity. If it gets tired of Musk‚Äôs lollygagging, Twitter could eventually sue to compel Musk to go through with the deal. In Musk‚Äôs most significant play yet to pull out of the deal, his lawyer sent a letter to Twitter accusing the company of denying Musk‚Äôs requests for more information about the number of fake and spam accounts on the platform. ‚ÄîNF Musk has repeatedly argued that Twitter has a much bigger bot problem than it discloses, and is using that as justification to scuttle (or potentially renegotiate) his $44 billion purchase. Twitter responded to Musk‚Äôs letter with a statement along the lines of, ‚ÄúNo take-backs, pal.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: The UK launched a major test of the 4-day workweek
item.description: . In January, there were just 1,700 jobs advertising a four-day workweek in the US for every 1 million posted. Become smarter in just 5 minutesGet the daily email that makes reading the news actually enjoyable. Bottom line: For all the notable trials and tests of a shorter workweek, finding a job that actually implements one is extremely rare. Trials of lighter work schedules haven‚Äôt always been successful for both employees and employers, though: A two-year trial of a six-hour workday in one of Sweden‚Äôs largest cities in 2017 left workers happier, healthier, and more productive, but the practice was deemed too expensive due to the new hires needed to fill gaps in time. More than 3,300 workers will participate in the trial, making it the largest test of the four-day workweek. A six-month program that began in the UK on Monday will test the effects of the four-day workweek on thousands of workers across 70 companies. ‚ÄîMK But, if you‚Äôre one of the 92% of US employees who are into the idea and don‚Äôt want to wait for trial results, you may want to consider moving to France, where a 35-hour workweek cap has been the law since 2000. The results of the trial will be announced sometime in 2023. Several industries will be involved, including banking, health care, marketing, and retail‚Äîand through interviews, surveys, and internal productivity measures, researchers will determine if we have all been clocking in on Fridays for our whole adult lives for absolutely no reason.
item.author: Max Knoblauch

item.title: Elon Musk tries to squirm out of Twitter deal

In Musk‚Äôs most significant play yet to pull out of the deal, his lawyer sent a letter to Twitter accusing the company of denying Musk‚Äôs requests for more information about the number of fake and spam accounts on the platform. ‚ÄîNF Musk has repeatedly argued that Twitter has a much bigger bot problem than it discloses, and is using that as justification to scuttle (or potentially renegotiate) his $44 billion purchase. Twitter responded to Musk‚Äôs letter with a statement along the lines of, ‚ÄúNo take-backs, pal.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Axon pumps the brakes on taser drone it said could take down mass shooters
item.description: . Become smarter in just 5 minutesGet the daily email that makes reading the news actually enjoyable. The hard pivot comes after Axon founder and CEO Rick Smith announced last week that the security company would start development of drones that could be operated by first responders and potentially used in schools to avoid another shooting like the recent one in Uvalde, Texas. The plan, one of several ‚Äúmaybe add more weapons?‚Äù ‚ÄîMM What changed? The board, a group of experts in tech, privacy, and policing, sparred publicly with Smith over the idea, arguing that the drones could be used to over-police communities of color. -type solutions to mass shootings, caused nine members of the company‚Äôs ethics board to resign yesterday.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: The UK launched a major test of the 4-day workweek
item.description: . In January, there were just 1,700 jobs advertising a four-day workweek in the US for every 1 million posted. Become smarter in just 5 minutesGet the daily email that makes reading the news actually enjoyable. Trials of lighter work schedules haven‚Äôt always been successful for both employees and employers, though: A two-year trial of a six-hour workday in one of Sweden‚Äôs largest cities in 2017 left workers happier, healthier, and more productive, but the practice was deemed too expensive due to the new hires needed to fill gaps in time. More than 3,300 workers will participate in the trial, making it the largest test of the four-day workweek. A six-month program that began in the UK on Monday will test the effects of the four-day workweek on thousands of workers across 70 companies. ‚ÄîMK But, if you‚Äôre one of the 92% of US employees who are into the idea and don‚Äôt want to wait for trial results, you may want to consider moving to France, where a 35-hour workweek cap has been the law since 2000. ü§ûFingers crossedü§ûThe concept of a four-day workweek is decades-old, but legitimate tests of it are somewhat recent. The results of the trial will be announced sometime in 2023. Several industries will be involved, including banking, health care, marketing, finance, and retail‚Äîand through interviews, surveys, and internal productivity measures, researchers will determine if we have all been clocking in on Fridays for our whole adult lives for absolutely no reason.
item.author: Max Knoblauch

item.title: "It ain't rocket science": How one FoodToker is making a career as a content creator
item.description: . Today‚Äôs dish is shrimp tempura udon and food content creator H Woo Lee is explaining how to make it from scratch in a behind-the-scenes video. Lee says he and TikToker Sam Way were the first ones to create ASMR cooking videos for TikTok.Become smarter in just 5 minutesGet the daily email that makes reading the news actually enjoyable. His videos are relaxing and stylish, concealing the hours of work he puts into creating TikToks for his 1 million followers. No one can taste my food,‚Äù Lee said. css-y2oq5g{display:-webkit-inline-box;display:-webkit-inline-flex;display:-ms-inline-flexbox;display:inline-flex;-webkit-appearance:none;-moz-appearance:none;-ms-appearance:none;appearance:none;-webkit-align-items:center;-webkit-box-align:center;-ms-flex-align:center;align-items:center;-webkit-box-pack:center;-ms-flex-pack:center;-webkit-justify-content:center;justify-content:center;-webkit-user-select:none;-moz-user-select:none;-ms-user-select:none;user-select:none;position:relative;white-space:nowrap;vertical-align:middle;outline:2px solid transparent;outline-offset:2px;width:auto;line-height:1.2;border-radius:var(--chakra-radii-md);font-weight:var(--chakra-fontWeights-semibold);transition-property:var(--chakra-transition-property-common);transition-duration:var(--chakra-transition-duration-normal);height:var(--chakra-sizes-10);min-width:var(--chakra-sizes-10);font-size:var(--chakra-fontSizes-md);-webkit-padding-start:var(--chakra-space-4);padding-inline-start:var(--chakra-space-4);-webkit-padding-end:var(--chakra-space-4);padding-inline-end:var(--chakra-space-4);color:var(--chakra-colors-white);background:var(--colors-primary);radius:var(--border-radius);}. Like a lot of food influencers, Lee isn‚Äôt a professional chef. His ultimate goal is to open a restaurant one day so his fans can finally taste his food. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs only one way for anyone to differentiate themselves. It‚Äôs like a miniature store,‚Äù Kar Brulhart, a creator strategist said. ‚ÄúIn-person dining, and like being a chef,‚Äù Lee said, ‚Äúthat‚Äôs my craft.‚Äù The 23 year old‚Äôs main channel has 92.6 million subscribers and makes at least $3 million per month from YouTube ads alone, per the analytics service SocialBlade. Creators like Lee are ditching the Instagram filters, highly posed pictures, and stylized lattes for content that feels more authentic. Lee compares being a content creator to being an Uber driver: He has the freedom to set his own work schedule, which is what he wanted for himself. These days successful creators are very knowledgeable in their respective fields while coming across as down to earth, but they deliver professional-grade content that is strategically planned and carefully edited, like Lee‚Äôs cooking videos. The rise of TikTok stars makes mastery of the app seem like an easy, glamorous, and highly rewarding side hustle, but for most creators, like Lee, that‚Äôs simply not true. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs so many creators coming into this space now,‚Äù Lee explained to Morning Brew. As a full-time creator, Lee makes ASMR-style videos (or to get technical: Autonomous Sensory Meridian) that feature elaborate dishes, like prosciutto arugula pizza and Peking duck, to stand out from his TikTok competitors. But first, he needs to continue producing good food and even better content until Gordon Ramsay comes knocking. It‚Äôs a laborious process that, for TikTok, was edited into a tidy 60-second video emphasizing the sounds of his kitchen: the boil of the broth, the sizzle of cooking oil, and Lee‚Äôs slurps as he eats his final product. He‚Äôs not just cooking intricate meals‚Äîhe‚Äôs also his own planner, cameraman, video editor, and social media manager. His very first viral video had 10.6 millions of views, but even after being a full-time creator for almost a year and half, he still can‚Äôt recreate the recipe to that success every time.
item.author: Sherry Qin

item.title: The inglorious return of cheese rolling
item.description: . Become smarter in just 5 minutesGet the daily email that makes reading the news actually enjoyable. This year that glory belonged to Chris Anderson, the Joey Chestnut of extreme cheese rolling. css-y2oq5g[data-hover][data-disabled]{background:var(--colors-primary);opacity:0.5;}SubscribeMillennials have done crazy things for a cheese board, but they‚Äôve got nothing on the ‚Äúathletes‚Äù who competed in this weekend‚Äôs cheese rolling extreme sporting event in England. css-1dlcpt7[data-readonly]{box-shadow:none! The more you know: The centuries-old cheese rolling event is thought to have originated from a pagan festival celebrating the onset of spring. It was Anderson‚Äôs 23rd cheese title‚Äîbut also his last.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: New York moves to put a moratorium on some bitcoin mining permits
item.description: . Become smarter in just 5 minutesGet the daily email that makes reading the news actually enjoyable. New York‚Äôs state Senate passed a bill on Friday that would ban new permits across the state for bitcoin mining facilities that use carbon-based power. css-1dlcpt7[data-readonly]{box-shadow:none! css-y2oq5g[data-hover][data-disabled]{background:var(--colors-primary);opacity:0.5;}SubscribeUpstate New York offers a wonderful range of activities, from hiking in the Adirondacks to inhaling a garbage plate in Rochester.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Apple prepares for a world after smartphones
item.description: . What we know about Apple‚Äôs AR and VR playZuck‚Äôs obsession with the metaverse gets all the headlines, but Apple CEO Tim Cook has been hyping up mixed reality‚Äîthe mashup of physical and virtual words‚Äîfor at least six years. item.description: . Become smarter in just 5 minutesGet the daily email that makes reading the news actually enjoyable. The more you know: The centuries-old cheese rolling festival is thought to have originated from a pagan festival celebrating the onset of spring. It was Anderson‚Äôs 23rd cheese title‚Äîbut also his last.

item.title: NASA taps two companies to develop lunar spacesuits
item.description: . Become smarter in just 5 minutesGet the daily email that makes reading the news actually enjoyable. NASA will test the companies‚Äô suits in 2025, and then decide whether to fund one or both designs. One major reason for the holdup is that the necessary spacesuits won‚Äôt be ready on time. It‚Äôs been a leading aerospace supplier for decades and has supplied spacesuits to NASA before. Hoping to finally fix its spacesuit production snags, NASA announced this week that it awarded contracts to two teams led by private companies, Axiom Space and Collins Aerospace, to make its suits. NASA‚Äôs outsourcing is a tacit admission that its own work developing lunar suits in-house for 15 years has been too costly and time-consuming: As of August 2021, NASA‚Äôs spacesuit production schedule has suffered more than 20 months of delays. Construction of the rocket and the lunar lander have been set back by Covid-19 supply and labor challenges, as well as a legal scuffle between NASA and Jeff Bezos‚Äôs Blue Origin after NASA chose Elon Musk‚Äôs SpaceX to build the lander. In the end, the whole endeavor was such a slog that NASA finally decided to bring in Axiom Space and Collins Aerospace to help outfit its astronauts. Meanwhile, newcomer Axiom Space was founded in 2016 with the goal of building the first private space station. So, constructing a spacesuit is a Sisyphean task to start with, and NASA faced major hurdles trying to produce them in-house:1. Last year, NASA only received 77% of the funding it requested for part of the lunar program, resulting in a $69 million budget shortfall for suit development and a delay of at least three months. Looking ahead‚Ä¶even if NASA astronauts get the right gear to go to the moon in time, the lunar mission has to overcome several other major obstacles. *sigh*‚ÄîJW What‚Äôs the holdup, exactly?
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.description: . Become smarter in just 5 minutesGet the daily email that makes reading the news actually enjoyable. That‚Äôs not in line with who I am and I don‚Äôt have to do that anymore. I don‚Äôt consider winning to be hitting a home run every time you get up to the plate. css-y2oq5g{display:-webkit-inline-box;display:-webkit-inline-flex;display:-ms-inline-flexbox;display:inline-flex;-webkit-appearance:none;-moz-appearance:none;-ms-appearance:none;appearance:none;-webkit-align-items:center;-webkit-box-align:center;-ms-flex-align:center;align-items:center;-webkit-box-pack:center;-ms-flex-pack:center;-webkit-justify-content:center;justify-content:center;-webkit-user-select:none;-moz-user-select:none;-ms-user-select:none;user-select:none;position:relative;white-space:nowrap;vertical-align:middle;outline:2px solid transparent;outline-offset:2px;width:auto;line-height:1.2;border-radius:var(--chakra-radii-md);font-weight:var(--chakra-fontWeights-semibold);transition-property:var(--chakra-transition-property-common);transition-duration:var(--chakra-transition-duration-normal);height:var(--chakra-sizes-10);min-width:var(--chakra-sizes-10);font-size:var(--chakra-fontSizes-md);-webkit-padding-start:var(--chakra-space-4);padding-inline-start:var(--chakra-space-4);-webkit-padding-end:var(--chakra-space-4);padding-inline-end:var(--chakra-space-4);color:var(--chakra-colors-white);background:var(--colors-primary);radius:var(--border-radius);}. But Frankel isn‚Äôt just a TV star‚Äîshe‚Äôs also a super savvy businessperson. My first time trying to get on The Apprentice, I think, ‚ÄúI‚Äôve made it‚Äù and they tell me, "You didn‚Äôt make it.‚Äù I consider winning how you handle it. css-1dlcpt7[data-readonly]{box-shadow:none!

item.title: Study: Moderate coffee drinkers show lower mortality rates
item.description: . Become smarter in just 5 minutesGet the daily email that makes reading the news actually enjoyable. ) had a lower mortality rate than people who didn‚Äôt drink any coffee. A study published this week in the journal Annals of Internal Medicine found that people who drink 1.5 to 3.5 cups of coffee a day (even if they add a little bit of sugar to it! ‚ÄîMM css-1dlcpt7[data-readonly]{box-shadow:none! But it doesn‚Äôt conclusively prove that coffee itself is the panacea:Dr. Christina Wee, an associate professor at Harvard Medical School and the deputy editor of the journal, told the NYT that other characteristics of coffee drinkers could be contributing to their lower mortality rate, such as diet and exercise. The researchers, who studied 171,000 people in the UK over a seven-year period, found that coffee drinkers were 30% less likely to die during the study period than the coffee-less.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Russia invaded Ukraine 100 days ago
item.description: . Become smarter in just 5 minutesGet the daily email that makes reading the news actually enjoyable. But it appears to be fading from many Americans‚Äô radars: Social media interactions on news articles about Ukraine have decreased from 109 million in the first week of the war to 4.8 million last week, per Axios. On Thursday, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky said that Russia has increased its territorial control to 20%. Zelensky said this week that 60‚Äì100 Ukrainian soldiers are dying every day in the conflict, in addition to the tens of thousands of civilians who have been killed since Feb. 24, per Ukrainian estimates. But, despite failing in its initial aims to topple the Ukrainian government, Russia appears set on defending the territory it has already seized. ‚ÄîJW So where do we stand? css-1dlcpt7[data-readonly]{box-shadow:none! css-y2oq5g[data-hover][data-disabled]{background:var(--colors-primary);opacity:0.5;}SubscribeYesterday marked 100 days since Russia invaded Ukraine in a brazen move that has shaken up the post-Cold War geopolitical order, caused economic hardships all over the globe, and displaced millions of people from their homes.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: CEOs are warning of a recession; the economic data isn‚Äôt saying the same
item.description: . Become smarter in just 5 minutesGet the daily email that makes reading the news actually enjoyable. While some leading CEOs are sounding the alarm on a recession, the actual economic data isn‚Äôt saying the same thing. Musk is one of several prominent execs who has recently said that the fight against inflation + the war in Ukraine are about to send the economy into the Bad Place. It showed the US economy added a meaty 390,000 jobs last month and the unemployment rate held steady at a super low 3.6%.
item.author: Neal Freyman
